title.narrative: INTEGRATED CHILD RIGHTS MONITRORING

description.narrative: Output 3.3: A framework for an integrated Child Rights Monitoring system is endorsed by relevant authorities at national and local levels and civil society social sector indicators for children's rights are aligned with international standards., which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance (Covid), Children With Disabilities, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Data And Child Protection, Evaluation And Research, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 3: The Government of Kazakhstan fosters opportunities for State institutions, civil society, private sector, academia, the media and the International community to mobilize support, capacity and resources to advance the rights of vulnerable children and adolescents, within and beyond the borders of Kazakhstan.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 3.3: A framework for an integrated Child Rights Monitoring system is endorsed by relevant authorities at national and locallevels and civil society; social sector indicators for children?s rights are aligned with international standards.

description.narrative: Throughout 2020, UNICEF supported several initiatives of the Child Rights Protection Committee of MOES (CRP Committee) in Child Wellbeing Index (CWI) development, cross-border conference on sharing the neighboring countries’ experiences in child wellbeing measurement and child budget, meetings with international experts; UNICEF engaged international expertise (Innocenti Office of Research) and achieved the consent of the national partner for coordinated actions in developing the tailored Kazakhstan CWI model, using UNICEF experience and resources. The CWI model is to be operational in 2022 across the country. | Status:Met | As-of Date:18/01/2021

title.narrative: Number of cities & districts certified as child-friendly(41911)

target.value: 2020:CFC assessment and certification system is automated and tested

title.narrative: Availability of comprehensive, up-to-date and integrated data on the status of childrens rights (child wellbeing) at district and central levels; level of accessibility of data (by sex, age, and disability status)(41907)

baseline.value: Data collection systems, including the range, scope and level of disaggregation on children are not sufficient to enable effective monitoring and evaluation of the general situation on children; the a

target.value: 2020:comprehensive, up-to-date and integrated data on child wellbeing is available at district and central levels; data on the status of childrens rights is available for annual Parliamentary review

actual.value: 2020:Yearbook for Children of Kazakhstan is issued by Bureau of Statistics for 2020. MICS is under consideration for funding by the Government.

title.narrative: Degree of alignment of priority* social sector indicators for Childrens Rights with international standards * Areas of priority include: Child Poverty, Child Protection and Child Care, Justice for Children, Violence against Children, Child with Disability and Mental Health(41908)

baseline.value: Indicators are not fully aligned with international standards

target.value: 2020:all priority SDG indicators related to children are nationalized

actual.value: 2020:All 52 child-related SDG indicators are nationalized by the Government of Kazakhstan.

title.narrative: % of child rights monitoring funded from the national budget(41910)

baseline.value: Not available. However, 38% of MICS5 was funded from the national budget

target.value: 2020:50% of national child rights monitoring systems/ instruments is funded from the national budget

actual.value: 2020:Yearbook is fully financed by the Statistics Bureau. The Government allocated funds for CWBI development. The funding for MICS is pending approval.

title.narrative: Availability of a costed and evaluated model for monitoring the status of Child Rights at oblast level(41909)

baseline.value: Pilot for a Child Wellbeing monitoring system is underway at oblast level

target.value: 2020:a costed and evaluated model for monitoring Child Rights at oblast level is available for scale-up

actual.value: 2020:CWB model documented for scale-up and national advocacy is continued.
